Next, select the desired class under <Color(-34022)>Additional</Color> to display a list of available actions. Highlighting the checkbox will add the action to the list at the bottom of the Actions & Traits interface.

Once an action has been added to the list, <Color(-34022)>drag</Color> the icon to your <Color(-34022)>hotbar</Color> to ready it for use.

Player attributes such as <Color(-34022)>strength</Color>, which affects physical attack power, and <Color(-34022)>vitality</Color>, which affects maximum HP, can be viewed by selecting <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

Upon attaining level 10 in a class, you will begin earning <Color(-34022)>attribute points</Color>. These points can be allocated to any attribute, allowing for further class customization.

For example, increasing <Color(-34022)>strength</Color> will improve attack power, while increasing <Color(-34022)>mind</Color> will strengthen the potency of Cure spells.

To allocate points, start by pressing the golden <Color(-34022)>+</Color> button located next to Attributes on the Character window. This will open the <Color(-34022)>Point Allotment</Color> window. Next, select the attributes you wish to increase and press <Color(-34022)>Accept</Color> to finalize the allocation. Once you have allotted a point, it cannot be removed, so make your decision carefully. Classes belonging to the Disciplines of the Hand and the Land are not granted attribute points.

Instanced raids come with several rules─including time limits and restrictions on changing classes or jobs. Instanced areas can be left at any time by using an <Color(-34022)>exit</Color> or selecting <Color(-34022)>Leave</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color>, but by doing so, remember that you will be abandoning your party in the process. Exits will also appear after defeating a raid boss, allowing your party easy access out of the area without having to backtrack.

Once the raid boss has been encountered, players will be unable to enter or leave the immediate area. Make sure that all your party members are nearby and prepared before entering the final battle, lest you incur their undying wrath.
If you are KO'd during an instanced raid, you may either have a party member <Color(-34022)>Raise</Color> you, or choose to return to the instance entrance.
Your main weapon determines your current class. Changing classes is as easy as equipping a different type of weapon or tool to your <Color(-34022)>Main Hand</Color> slot.

<Color(-34022)>Gear sets</Color> allow you to save several different combinations of equipment and swap them at your leisure. A button for the Gear Set interface is located in the upper portion of the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> window.

This can be a very convenient feature for players who regularly switch back and forth between various classes, as well as for players who wish to have ready multiple sets of gear for the different types of duties they undertake, such as PvP or instanced raids.

Select the <Color(-34022)>+</Color> button to register your currently equipped gear as a new set.

You are about to enter a special instance. These areas are reserved for important battles which feature unique environmental conditions or powerful boss enemies. Instance objectives can be confirmed in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>.

For the duration of the battle, you will be unable to pass beyond the <Color(-34022)>red line</Color> displayed on the field.

You will automatically leave the instance once all quest objectives have been met.

A myriad of items can be bought and sold from vendors all across Eorzea. Purchasing an item is as simple as clicking on an item in a shopkeep's inventory, while selling an item is as simple as dragging an item from your inventory or Armoury Chest. You can also sell items by right-clicking them and selecting <Color(-34022)>Sell</Color>.
If you happen to have second thoughts about a sale, you can always <Color(-34022)>buy back</Color> your item from the vendor, but only if you have yet to leave the area or log out of the game.

Each shop has its own <Color(-34022)>inventory</Color>. This number directly affects the asking price of all items in stock. The fewer items a shop has in its inventory, the higher the asking price. When a price has fluctuated, a special icon will appear next to the corresponding item's name.
When a transaction you make has affected an item's asking price, the difference in gil will appear above the icon and a system message will be displayed in your log.

Disciples of Magic and Disciples of War who specialize in ranged attacks (such as archers) are best suited fighting their targets from a distance. The range and radius of an action can also be confirmed in the help window.

Since the Armoury system in FINAL FANTASY XIV allows you to change your class or job by simply changing the weapon or tool in your main hand, it is recommended that you always have several sets of gear on hand. However, gear can take up a tremendous amount of space in one's inventory, which is why all adventurers carry an </Color>Armoury Chest</Color>.

All gear purchased, crafted, or found is automatically stored in this chest, leaving your inventory free to fill with other items such as potions, crafting materials, and food.

Gear in your Armoury Chest is categorized and sorted by type, and can be equipped or discarded directly from the chest interface.

The Armoury Chest can be accessed at any time by selecting <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> from the main menu followed by <Color(-34022)>Armoury Chest</Color>, or pressing <Color(-34022)>Ctrl+I</Color>.

A crescent moon icon will appear below your <Color(-34022)>experience bar</Color> whenever you enter a <Color(-34022)>sanctuary</Color>. While in this special area, you will accrue a <Color(-34022)>rested bonus</Color>. The bonus will continue to grow even if you are offline.
All experience earned through battle, crafting, and gathering while under the benefit of the rested bonus will be increased by 50%.

Your current rested bonus is displayed on top of your experience bar. The dark orange bar shows how much more experience can be earned before the bonus fades. If the bar is blue, it indicates your bonus will carry over to the next level.

Inns in all three city-states, as well as various outposts and settlements, are classified as sanctuaries. To maximize your experience-earning potential, make it a habit to always log out in one of these areas.

You have formed a <Color(-34022)>party</Color> with another player! Parties make it possible to tackle challenges that would be impossible to overcome alone, such as defeating powerful enemies or exploring perilous dungeons.
The Party chat mode can be used to communicate solely with the other members of your party. You can change your chat mode at any time via the <Color(-34022)>tabs</Color> located below the chat log.

While in a party, a list of your party's members is displayed on the left side of the screen. This can be used to quickly identify each member's current condition. You can also target party members by clicking on their name in the list. This is especially helpful when there are many objects on the screen and it is difficult or time-consuming to target a member by ordinary means.

Your party will sometimes be awarded boosts to various attributes based on class and job combinations. If your party is receiving one of these bonuses, it will be indicated by a <Color(-34022)>party bonus icon</Color> located above your <Color(-34022)>party list</Color>.

Remember, your party members are all the in-game embodiment of real, living people, and chances are you will see them again online. Karma is alive and well in Eorzea. Treat people well, and your life in Eorzea will be a pleasant one. Treat them poorly, and it will come back to you.

The <Color(-34022)>player search</Color> feature found in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color> can be used to easily and instantly locate other logged-in player characters (PCs). Searches will list up to 200 results, starting with the ones which are physically closest to your own character.

Selecting <Color(-34022)>Search Conditions</Color> will open a new window in which you can specify the conditions of your search to produce more accurate results. Options include partial name searches for both first and last names, as well as searching by online status, class, level, location, or languages spoken. Press the <Color(-34022)>Execute</Color> button to initiate your search.

If there are any players who meet the conditions specified, they will be displayed in the social lists window. You can right-click on player names to view their search info.

To allow your character to be included in searches for multiple classes, first change your online status to <Color(-34022)>Looking for Party</Color>, then select the corresponding icons. If no class is highlighted, then you will only be included in searches for your current class.

If multiple classes are highlighted, the last one clicked will have a thicker border than the others. This indicates to other players that while you have other classes at your disposal, this is the particular one you wish to play as.

Whenever you open a treasure coffer, a <Color(-34022)>loot list</Color> will appear. If someone in your party opens a coffer, you will first receive a <Color(-34022)>notice</Color> in the bottom right-hand corner of your screen. Clicking on this notice will bring up the loot list.

For each item in the chest, you will have the opportunity to select <Color(-34022)>Need</Color>, <Color(-34022)>Greed</Color>, or <Color(-34022)>Pass</Color>.

Need: You really need the item.
Greed: You want the item, but do not need it.
Pass: You do not need the item.

Once everyone in your party has made their selections, the loot will be distributed automatically.

If only one member has chosen Need, that player will receive the item. If multiple players have chosen Need, they will each throw <Color(-34022)>dice</Color> to determine who receives the item. If no one has chosen Need, then those players who chose Greed will roll the dice. If all party members choose Pass, then the item will be discarded.
Only players who can equip the item in question as their current class or job will be allowed to select Need. All others may only select Greed or Pass.
Gil and quest-related items will be divided evenly amongst all party members.

Whenever you open a treasure coffer, a <Color(-34022)>loot list</Color> will appear. If someone in your party opens a coffer, you will first receive a <Color(-34022)>notice</Color> in the bottom right-hand corner of your screen. Selecting this notice will bring up the loot list.

When forming a party with other players, you will sometimes be awarded boosts to various attributes. If your party is receiving one of these bonuses, it will be indicated in the <Color(-34022)>party bonus icon</Color> located above your <Color(-34022)>party list</Color>.

The type of bonuses received is determined by the class or job of each party member. These bonuses do not stack, so if the class of two party members happens to trigger the same bonus, the party will only receive an attribute boost from one.

Party bonuses are granted to all members, and last until the party has been dissolved.

Gathering a party that will maximize attribute bonuses is one strategy that may prove useful when tackling more difficult foes.

Limit breaks are powerful actions which are only available to parties of four or more members. The actions can be executed when the party's <Color(-34022)>limit gauge</Color> is full. The gauge is located directly above the <Color(-34022)>party list</Color>.

The limit gauge will slowly fill as battle progresses, while certain acts of heroism─such as curing an ally while they are on the brink of death, or preventing an enemy from using its special attack─will cause the gauge to rise quicker.

The <Color(-34022)>Limit Break</Color> trigger is located in the <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color> menu under <Color(-34022)>General</Color>. It can be set to your <Color(-34022)>hotbar</Color> for easy access.

There are four different types of limit breaks: single attacks (melee), area of effect attacks (caster), defense (tank), and healing (healer and ranged). Which type is used depends on the class/job of the person who initiates the action.
Limit gauge length varies depending on party size and battle type. The more party members you have, and the more difficult the foe you face, the more options you will have.
<Color(-34022)>Level sync</Color> is a system which allows players to participate in lower level duties by temporarily adjusting their levels, and is available for most FATEs and instanced raids.

When your level is synced, not only your personal attributes, but the attributes of your gear will automatically be lowered to meet the requirements set by the duty in which you are participating. Once the duty ends, everything is restored to its original state.
Experience earned while level synced is based off the synced level, not your current level; however, it will be added to the progress of the latter.

While using a job, you will have limited access to actions from other classes. You will, however, have access to new, job-specific actions.
Job level and attribute bonuses coincide with those of the base class. When a job level rises, so, too, does the level of the base class, and vice versa.

The <Color(-34022)>linkshell</Color> feature is now available!

Linkshells are chat groups which allow for quick and easy communication between players who are not necessarily in a party or free company.
Linkshells can have up to <Color(-34022)>128</Color> members, while players may possess as many as <Color(-34022)>eight</Color> separate linkshells.

Upon reaching level 10, you will be allowed to rent chocobos from stables across Eorzea. Chocobos can be used for speedy transport to areas which are not readily accessible via aetheryte.

While riding, you will have complete control over the chocobo until you either dismount or are attacked, or the rental period expires.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear near your parameter bar indicating how much time is remaining before the rental period expires. You can dismount the rental chocobo at any time by right-clicking this icon. Be aware, however, that once you have dismounted, the chocobo will return to his stables, regardless of how much time is remaining.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear near your parameter bar indicating how much time is remaining before the rental period expires. You can dismount the rental chocobo at any time by selecting this icon. Be aware, however, that once you have dismounted, the chocobo will return to his stables, regardless of how much time is remaining.

<Color(-34022)>Chocobo porters</Color> are similar to rental chocobos in that they can be hired to carry you quickly to destinations throughout Eorzea, the differences being that you cannot control these birds, and that they will not stop until they have arrived at their destination. On the other hand, chocobo porters are trained to take the safest route, meaning that they will never be attacked while in transit.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear in your status effects bar. You can dismount the chocobo porter at any time by clicking this icon. Be aware, however, that once you have dismounted, the chocobo will continue on to his destination, leaving you behind.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear in your status effects bar. You can dismount the chocobo porter at any time by selecting this icon. Be aware, however, that once you have dismounted, the chocobo will continue on to his destination, leaving you behind.

You can <Color(-34022)>use</Color> a <Color(-34022)>chocobo whistle</Color> to acquire the <Color(-34022)>action</Color> to summon your personal chocobo. Unlike rental chocobos, there is no time limit regulating how long you may remain on chocoback. Remember, however, there are areas, such as highly populated cities and narrow dungeons, that your chocobo will refuse to enter.

The action to summon your chocobo can be set to your <Color(-34022)>hotbar</Color> and is located under <Color(-34022)>Mounts</Color> found on the <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color> interface in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.
If you are attacked while on chocoback, your steed may buck you and run off to safety. You may only summon him again once the immediate threat has been neutralized.
Chocobo armor, or “barding,” can be equipped via the <Color(-34022)>Companions</Color> interface situated in the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear in your status effects bar. You can dismount your chocobo at any time by right-clicking this icon or by reclicking the <Color(-34022)>action</Color> you used to mount your steed. Use the chocobo whistle to summon your steed again.

While on chocoback, a <Color(-34022)>chocobo icon</Color> will appear in your status effects bar. You can dismount your chocobo at any time by selecting this icon or by reselecting the <Color(-34022)>action</Color> you used to mount your steed. Use the chocobo whistle to summon your steed again.

In addition to riding him, you can also summon your chocobo to fight alongside you. To do so, you will first require a bunch of <Color(-34022)>gysahl greens</Color>. This chocobo favorite can be purchased in stores.

To summon your chocobo, simply <Color(-34022)>use</Color> the greens. As a rule, chocobos can only fight in the same places in which they can be ridden, so don't expect your faithful steed to follow you into the depths of dungeons like the Tam–Tara Deepcroft or Copperbell Mines.

Once summoned to battle, your chocobo will remain with you for 30 minutes (Earth time), or until he suffers injuries grievous enough to make him flee.

To give your companion orders, use the commands located under <Color(-34022)>Companions</Color> in the Actions & Traits interface.
To order your chocobo to auto-attack, simply select <Color(-34022)>Free Stance</Color>. You can dismiss your companion at any time by selecting the command <Color(-34022)>Withdraw</Color>.
Use another bunch of gysahl greens to summon your steed again.
As your chocobo's rank increases, he will earn skill points (<Color(-34022)>SP</Color>). These points can be used to acquire new companion-specific actions and traits.

There are three different skill trees you can choose for your chocobo: <Color(-34022)>Defender</Color>, <Color(-34022)>Attacker</Color>, and <Color(-34022)>Healer</Color>. When your chocobo acquires his first skill from any of these trees, he will also learn that tree's <Color(-34022)>stance</Color>.

Activating the <Color(-34022)>Defender Stance</Color> will turn your chocobo into a defensive-minded stalwart. The <Color(-34022)>Attacker Stance</Color> will transform your chocobo into an offensive force. Finally, the <Color(-34022)>Healer Stance</Color> will have your chocobo focus on restoring your HP rather than participating in battle.

How you choose to use your chocobo's skill points is entirely up to you, but remember─once an action or trait has been purchased, that purchase cannot be undone. Think about how you wish to use your chocobo in battle and choose its path of progression wisely.

The <Color(-34022)>hunting log</Color> is a record of your completion of tasks involving the slaying of certain creatures. By completing these tasks, you will earn rewards and unlock new challenges. The log can be accessed via <Color(-34022)>Logs</Color> found in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>, or by pressing <Color(-34022)>H</Color> on your keyboard.

Once the log is open, select a class and difficulty to view the available challenges for that rank. Each challenge is marked with a class name and number, such as <Color(-34022)>Lancer 01</Color>. Below that name and number you will find the target, as well as how many of the target you must defeat. Hovering over the target name will display one of the areas in which the target can be located.
Targets indicated in your hunting log will have a special icon above their <Color(-34022)>display name</Color>, making it easier to locate the creatures.

The log can be accessed via <Color(-34022)>Logs</Color> found in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

You are now a member of a <Color(-34022)>Grand Company</Color> and have been assigned the rank of <Color(-34022)>private third class</Color>.

Your Grand Company and rank can be confirmed at any time under the <Color(-34022)>Profile</Color> tab in the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> interface accessed via the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

Grand Companies pay their members not in gil, but in company seals. You can confirm how many seals are currently in your possession under the <Color(-34022)>Currency</Color> tab.

Seals can be earned by completing various Grand Company missions.

A Grand Company <Color(-34022)>quartermaster</Color> is stationed at each Grand Company headquarters, and will exchange items for company seals. Company seals are only redeemable with the Grand Company that issued them.

The Grand Companies of Eorzea are in constant need of <Color(-34022)>supplies</Color> and <Color(-34022)>provisions</Color> to maintain their daily operations. Adventurers can earn experience points and <Color(-34022)>company seals</Color> by crafting or gathering the items required and delivering them. Speak to a Grand Company <Color(-34022)>quartermaster</Color> to complete the delivery.
Items sought change every day (Earth time). They can be confirmed by selecting <Color(-34022)>Timers</Color> located under <Color(-34022)>Duty</Color> in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

To bolster their strength, the Grand Companies of Eorzea seek donations of rare items whose names appear <Color(-34022)>green</Color> or <Color(-34022)>pink</Color> in their help window. <Color(-34022)>Aetherial gear</Color> is an example of such.
If you wish to make a donation. speak to a Grand Company <Color(-34022)>quartermaster</Color> to complete the delivery. You will be rewarded company seals for your contribution.

Free companies are independent player-operated organizations, not unlike guilds. While there are no restrictions on who may join a company, players cannot belong to more than one free company at a time.

Companies will advance in rank as they earn <Color(-34022)>company points</Color> by undertaking various group tasks. These tasks will also earn companies <Color(-34022)>credits</Color>, which can be used as currency to purchase various items.
To form a company, a player must first draft a petition and then get three other players to sign it. These three players will become the founding members of the company.

You have been asked to sign a free company petition. To form a new free company, a player must first obtain the signatures of three other people who agree to become the founding members of the company. If you wish to join, sign the petition!
You have joined a free company! Start by changing your chat mode to <Color(-34022)>Free Company</Color> and greeting the other members.

Selecting <Color(-34022)>Free Company</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>Social</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color> will display the Free Company interface. Here you can view company and member data, messages, and other important information.

Each member is assigned a <Color(-34022)>rank</Color>, each with various levels of </Color>authorization</Color>.
Depending on your rank, you may or may not be able to access such features as <Color(-34022)>promoting</Color> current members or <Color(-34022)>inviting</Color> new players.

As company members participate in various duties around Eorzea, they will not only earn experience points for themselves, but points for their free company as well. As company points are earned, the free company will increase in rank. As rank increases, new features such as <Color(-34022)>company crests</Color>, an expanded <Color(-34022)>company chest</Color>, and <Color(-34022)>housing</Color> become available.

The <Color(-34022)>company chest</Color> is a communal depository where free company members can store their excess gear and items. It can be accessed not only from the company's estate, but from Grand Company headquarters, and other convenient locations. Access rights are set by company leaders and can range from full access to all members to restricted access for a select few.

As the company increases in rank, additional compartments will be added to the chest, increasing the number of items which can be stored within.

Remember, unlike your personal inventory, the company chest is shared. To avoid misunderstandings with fellow company members, refrain from using the chest to store important personal effects.

Your free company can now create its own unique <Color(-34022)>company crest</Color>. To edit the company crest you must first have <Color(-34022)>authorization</Color> to do so. Next, you must speak with an <Color(-34022)>OIC officer of arms</Color> located at one of the three Grand Company of Eorzea headquarters.
Once your company has attained the proper rank, you will have the opportunity to apply the crest to pieces of armor for all the realm to see.

<Color(-34022)>Company Actions</Color> can be used to temporarily increase the statuses of all online company members. They can be accessed under <Color(-34022)>Actions</Color> in the <Color(-34022)>Free Company</Color> interface.

Actions can be purchased from <Color(-34022)>OIC quartermasters</Color> with <Color(-34022)>company credits</Color>. The higher your company's <Color(-34022)>standing</Color> with its Grand Company of allegiance, the fewer credits the actions will require.
To purchase, execute, disable, or discard actions, you must first have been granted the proper company <Color(-34022)>authorization</Color> to do so.

Speaking with a local distributor of guildleves, known as a <Color(-34022)>levemete</Color>, will bring up a list of available levequests. Highlight a quest to display its objectives, and select <Color(-34022)>Accept</Color> to add the quest to your <Color(-34022)>journal</Color>.

<Color(-34022)>Leve allowances</Color> are required to accept levequests. You will be granted three leve allowances every 12 hours (Earth time), up to a maximum of 100.

You may accept as many as 16 levequests at once.

To initiate a levequest, first open your <Color(-34022)>journal</Color> via the <Color(-34022)>Duty</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>, or by pressing <Color(-34022)>J</Color> on your keyboard. Next, select the levequest to bring up a detailed description of its objectives and its rewards.

Clicking on the <Color(-34022)>Map</Color> button will show the approximate location of the levequest's objectives. Though you can initiate a levequest at any time while in the corresponding area, it is recommended that you wait until you are close to the objectives before doing so. This will increase your chances of becoming eligible for completion bonuses.
Once you have arrived, open the journal, select the levequest, and click on the <Color(-34022)>Initiate</Color> button to begin your duty.

To initiate a levequest, first open your <Color(-34022)>journal</Color> via the <Color(-34022)>Duty</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>. Next, select the levequest to bring up a detailed description of its objectives and its rewards.

Selecting the <Color(-34022)>Map</Color> button will show the approximate location of the levequest's objectives. Though you can initiate a levequest at any time while in the corresponding area, it is recommended that you wait until you are close to the objectives before doing so. This will increase your chances of becoming eligible for completion bonuses.
Once you have arrived, open the journal, select the levequest, and press the <Color(-34022)>Initiate</Color> button to begin your duty.

When you initiate a levequest, you will be given the opportunity to adjust its difficulty. The greater the difficulty setting, the higher the level target enemies will be. Difficulty also affects completion rewards.

Levequest difficulty can be lowered at any time during the course of the duty by selecting the quest name in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color> and selecting <Color(-34022)>Difficulty</Color>.

Please note that levequest difficulty cannot be raised once the duty has been initiated.

Once you have initiated a levequest, the location of your quest objectives will be displayed on the <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>. Levequest targets can also be identified by the distinguishing icon displayed above their names.

During a levequest, the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color> is replaced with information regarding quest objectives, leve difficulty, time remaining, and more. Rewards are only granted to those who complete all the objectives listed within the time allotted.

When all levequest objectives have been completed, you will be given the option to return immediately to the issuing <Color(-34022)>levemete</Color> and collect your reward, though rewards can be collected at any time from any levemete in Eorzea.

If you fail to complete the levequest objectives within the allotted time, you can always rechallenge the quest by selecting it in your <Color(-34022)>journal</Color> and pressing the <Color(-34022)>Retry</Color> button. Rechallenging a levequest will cost one <Color(-34022)>leve allowance</Color>.

If you fail to complete the levequest objectives within the allotted time, you can always rechallenge the quest by selecting it in your <Color(-34022)>journal</Color> and pressing the <Color(-34022)>Retry</Color> button. Rechallenging a levequest will cost one <Color(-34022)>leve allowance</Color>.

<Color(-34022)>Tradecraft</Color> leves (guildleves for Disciples of the Hand) are governed by a different set of rules than their <Color(-34022)>battlecraft</Color> counterparts (guildleves for Disciples of War and Magic). For example, tradecraft leves have no time limit, and are considered complete when the items requested have been delivered to the client. Information on leve objectives as well as client location can be viewed in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>.

After creating all the requested items, speak with the client to bring up the trade window. Drag the items from your inventory into the trade window and click <Color(-34022)>Hand Over</Color> to complete the transaction. Submitting <Color(-34022)>HQ</Color> items will earn you a greater reward.

After creating all the requested items, speak with the client to bring up the trade window. Select the items from your inventory into the trade window and select <Color(-34022)>Hand Over</Color> to complete the transaction. Submitting <Color(-34022)>HQ</Color> items will earn you a greater reward.

<Color(-34022)>Fieldcraft</Color> leves (guildleves for Disciples of the Land) follow the same set of rules as their <Color(-34022)>battlecraft</Color> counterparts (guildleves for Disciples of War and Magic). There are, however, two main differences: you cannot begin a fieldcraft levequest unless you have changed to the corresponding class, and you must perform these tasks solo.

Leves for <Color(-34022)>Fishers</Color>, on the other hand, follow the same set of rules as tradecraft leves, in that you will be required to deliver your catch to the client in person. And, just as with leves for Disciples of the Hand, high-quality fish will earn you heftier rewards.

Once a leve has been initiated, its objectives will appear in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>. Fieldcraft leve objectives range from visiting specified locations to gathering the specified number of items, all within the allotted time limit.

Levequest targets are indicated with a <Color(-34022)>leveplate icon</Color> displayed above their <Color(-34022)>display names</Color>. The general location of targets is also marked on your <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>.
If you possess the same guildleve as the one activated by your party, a leve link will occur, ensuring that you receive full recompense upon completing the quest.

FATE is short for <Color(-34022)>Full Active Time Event</Color>. These public quests occur periodically in real time around Eorzea, and anyone can participate by simply showing up before one ends. When you sense a FATE nearby, a message will appear on your screen, and the location will be displayed on your maps.
The type of FATE in progress can be identified by its map icon. Mousing over the icon will display the FATE title.
You will automatically join a FATE the moment you cross the event threshold. At this time, the FATE title, objectives, and time remaining will appear in your <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>.

If you are currently more than six levels over the recommended level, a <Color(-34022)>Level Sync</Color> button will appear in your duty list. Press the button to automatically lower your level so that you may participate and receive rewards.
Once a FATE is complete, a window detailing your reward will be displayed. Rewards are distributed to all event participants and are based not only on success, but on individual contributions.

The more active you are in completing event objectives, the greater your contribution will be deemed. Contribution is indicated via the gold, silver, or bronze medal that appears on your reward window.

<Color(-34022)>Guildhests</Color> are special operations organized by Adventurers' Guilds and overseen by NPCs known as <Color(-34022)>battlewardens</Color>. Speaking with a battlewarden displays a list of all guildhests currently available. Please note, however, that each operation has conditions (such as <Color(-34022)>level</Color> or <Color(-34022)>class</Color>) that must be met by all party members before the duty can be commenced.

At first, you may find that only a limited number of guildhests are accessible, but do not worry. As you progress in level, that number will grow. If you are in a party, only operations that are accessible by all members will be displayed in the battlewarden's list.

Guildhests can also be accessed via the <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color>, removing the hassle of having to try and gather a party.

Once you have commenced a guildhest, the operation's objectives and the time remaining to complete them will appear in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>. Hints helpful to completing guildhest objectives will sometimes appear on screen. These hints will also be added to the duty list after being displayed.

If you are unable to complete the objectives within the allotted time, the guildhest will be deemed a failure.

While participating in guildhests, you may notice areas that are colored differently than the surrounding landscape. This color is to warn players that stepping into the hazardous zones will trigger new enemies to appear. Take care when passing nearby.

If you are KO'd while participating in a guildhest, you will be given the option to return to the <Color(-34022)>starting point of the operation</Color>, rather than all the way back to your home point.

If you successfully complete all guildhest objectives in the time allotted, you will be eligible for a reward. Speak with the <Color(-34022)>battlewarden</Color> overseeing the operation to collect it. If your party can complete the objectives without suffering a single casualty, you will be rewarded a special bonus.

You are now able to change your Grand Company of <Color(-34022)>allegiance</Color>. To proceed with the necessary paperwork, speak with a <Color(-34022)>personnel officer</Color> at any of the Grand Company headquarters.

Do note that upon changing allegiances, all assets (company seals) will be frozen, and some items, such as company-specific gear, may no longer be equippable. Furthermore, there is a cooling-off period of 30 days during which time you will be unable to apply for another transfer.

You can now craft items using <Color(-34022)>Quick Synthesis</Color>. Quick synthesis is available for any item you have successfully crafted at least once using traditional methods, and can significantly reduce the amount of time required to create multiple normal-quality items.

To begin quick synthesis, open your <Color(-34022)>Crafting Log</Color>, select the desired recipe, and then press the <Color(-34022)>Quick Synthesis</Color> button to the immediate left of the <Color(-34022)>Synthesize<Color(-34022)> button.
As quick synthesis only focuses on completing the recipe as fast as possible, it is difficult to produce high-quality items. If quality is your aim, normal synthesis is recommended.

All Disciples of the Hand receive a <Color(-34022)>crafting log</Color> which contains the recipes of every item they can synthesize. The crafting log can be opened by selecting <Color(-34022)>Logs</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.
To begin synthesis, you must first select the crafting class and level tier of the item you wish to create.

Once you have highlighted the item, confirm if you possess all the <Color(-34022)>materials</Color> necessary in your inventory. If you do, select the <Color(-34022)>Synthesize</Color> button to begin the crafting process.
Crafting is similar to battle in that various <Color(-34022)>actions</Color> are used to proceed.
Successfully crafting an item entails executing these synthesis actions to achieve 100% <Color(-34022)>progress</Color> before material <Color(-34022)>durability</Color> reaches zero.
If durability reaches zero before progress has reached 100%, the synthesis will fail and some of the materials may be lost.
Items that you have successfully crafted at least once will appear with a check mark to the left of their icons. Crafting an item for the first time will earn you a special experience point bonus.
Crafting is similar to battle in that various <Color(-34022)>actions</Color> are used to proceed.
Increasing an item's <Color(-34022)>quality</Color> during synthesis improves chances that the resulting product will be of a higher grade (<Color(-34022)>HQ</Color>).

Quality is normally improved by using <Color(-34022)>touch up</Color> actions. However, in addition to reducing material durability, these actions also require crafting points (<Color(-34022)>CP</Color>) to execute.
The higher the overall quality of a completed item, the higher the experience point reward will be.

Quality is normally improved by using <Color(-34022)>touch up</Color> actions. However, in addition to reducing material durability, these actions also require crafting points (<Color(-34022)>CP</Color>) to execute.
As synthesis progresses, material <Color(-34022)>condition</Color> will fluctuate between excellent and poor.

Using <Color(-34022)>Touch</Color> actions when condition is either <Color(-34022)>good</Color> or <Color(-34022)>excellent</Color> will result in greater increases in quality when the action is successful. Note, however, that in the following step, material condition will always drop to <Color(-34022)>poor</Color>.
Some recipes are aspected to one of the six elements─<Color(-34022)>fire, water, lightning, wind, earth, or ice</Color>─reducing the effectiveness of normal, unaspected synthesis.

In these cases, Disciple of the Hand actions such as <Color(-34022)>Brand of Wind</Color> or <Color(-34022)>Brand of Earth</Color> are recommended to change the aspect of the synthesis, allowing for smoother progress.
Every time you use an action, receive damage, or suffer a KO, the gear you have equipped is damaged. When your gear's condition reaches 0%, its functionality drops off severely.

Gear condition can be viewed by selecting <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>. The vertical bar situated next to each gear icon indicates approximate condition. An exact percentage can be viewed in the item help text by mousing over the icon.
NPCs conducting item repairs are indicated on your <Color(-34022)>map</Color> and <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color> by a hammer icon. For a small fee, they will restore an item's condition to 100%.
Disciples of the Hand have the ability to <Color(-34022)>repair</Color> their own items. To begin mending an item, select its icon and choose Repair.

Each item has class and level restrictions on who can repair it. This information can be viewed in an item's help text. In addition to meeting these restrictions, Disciples of the Hand must also use the proper grade of <Color(-34022)>dark matter</Color> to complete the repairs. Dark matter can be purchased from Grand Company quartermasters.

You have obtained a high-quality item! HQ items can be identified by their icon, as well as by the special mark that appears after their name.

<Color(-34022)>HQ</Color> gear will often have better stats than normal-quality items, while HQ materials used in synthesis will sometimes yield better results. These features make them more attractive to prospective buyers, resulting in higher selling prices.
HQ items cannot be stacked with normal-quality items.

You have obtained a <Color(-34022)>unique</Color> item.

As this item is special, you can never possess more than one at a time.
An item you have equipped is now <Color(-34022)>bound</Color> to you and can no longer be traded or put up for sale in the markets.

Most items can be sold and traded freely before they are used in battle, crafting, or gathering. This is true regardless of whether or not they have been equipped. However, performing one of these three actions after equipping a new piece of gear will bind the item to you, preventing future trade or sale to other players (NPC shops will still purchase bound items).
There exist some items that are marked as untradable. These cannot be traded or sold to other players under any condition.

Once an item is bound to you, it can never be unbound. The same is true for untradable items. Once one is in your possession, the only way to relieve yourself of it is by discarding the item, or selling it to an NPC. Remember this when opening treasure coffers with your party. It is always wise to make sure you absolutely need an item before attempting to claim it.

The <Color(-34022)>markets</Color> are a venue in which players from across the realm can either sell their own items using hired hands known as <Color(-34022)>retainers</Color> or purchase the items of another. The markets can be accessed by targeting and selecting one of the many <Color(-34022)>market boards</Color> conveniently located throughout Eorzea's towns and city-states.

The markets of Limsa Lominsa, Gridania, and Ul'dah are all connected, meaning that items put up for sale in one city-state can be viewed as well as purchased by players accessing the markets in a second city-state.

Sifting through the sheer number of items up for sale in the markets can prove an overwhelming task for those not familiar with the system. As most gear required for the first few levels of any class can be easily found at local NPC-run shops, it is recommended that players start here, and then work their way to the markets once they feel those shops can no longer meet their needs.

Before you can purchase an item from the markets, you must first find it. There are two different ways you can do this─one involves doing a direct search by typing in the name of the item you seek. The second consists of specifying search conditions to bring up a list of corresponding items.

If you know the exact name of the item you seek, then you need only type it in the <Color(-34022)>Free Search</Color> box and then press the <Color(-34022)>Search</Color> button located in the lower left-hand corner of the window. Typing an incomplete entry will bring up all items that begin with those letters. For example, typing <Color(-34022)>Boarskin Cr</Color> will display both Boarskin Crakows and Boarskin Crakows of Gathering.

If you would rather list all items that fall under a certain category, start by specifying search conditions from <Color(-34022)>Main Arm</Color>, <Color(-34022)>Armor</Color>, or <Color(-34022)>Items</Color> located under <Color(-34022)>Category Search</Color>. For example, if you wanted to view all footwear equippable by level 35 archers, you would first click on the <Color(-34022)>Feet</Color> icon under Armor, set the level indicator to <Color(-34022)>35</Color>, and then finally click the <Color(-34022)>Search </Color> button.
If there are any matches to your search, they will be displayed in the window to the right. The number to the right of the name indicates how many of the item are available for purchase.

Typing an incomplete entry will bring up all items that begin with those letters.
