For example, if you wanted to view all footwear equippable by level 35 archers, you would first select the <Color(-34022)>Feet</Color> icon under <Color(-34022)>Armor</Color>, set the level indicator to <Color(-34022)>35</Color>, and then finally select the <Color(-34022)>Search</Color> button.
If an item in the search list is available for purchase, you can select the icon to bring up a second list indicating the item's selling prices, ordered from lowest to highest.

Select the item you wish to buy to display a final prompt from which you can confirm or cancel the transaction.

A transaction fee will be charged for purchasing an item from a market outside the city-state you are currently in.
If you have a <Color(-34022)>retainer</Color> in your employ, you can have her place items up for sale in the markets. A <Color(-34022)>5%</Color> tax is charged to every sale.

To put an item up for sale, you must first entrust it to your retainer. Next, select the <Color(-34022)>Markets</Color> icon located in the upper right-hand corner of the retainer's inventory. Finally, select items from the inventory to put up for sale.

Items that are <Color(-34022)>untradable</Color> or <Color(-34022)>bound</Color> to you cannot be sold to other players, therefore you will be unable to move them from your retainer's inventory to the Market window.

The Retainer interface is being retooled for phase 3 of the beta test, and therefore has not been optimized for gamepad controls. For the duration of phase 2, we ask that players use a mouse when accessing their retainers.

<Color(-34022)>Summoning bells</Color> are used to call forth any retainers you have in your employ. Retainers are helpful NPCs who can be hired by players to maintain items and gil, as well as place goods up for sale in the markets.

Once you have been given approval to hire a retainer, speak with <Color(-34022)>Frydwyb</Color> in Limsa Lominsa, <Color(-34022)>Parnell</Color> in Gridania, or <Color(-34022)>Chachabi</Color> in Ul'dah to have them draft a contract of employment. You may hire no more than two retainers at a time.
<Color(-34022)>Retainers</Color> are helpful NPCs who can be hired by players to carry out such tasks as storing excess gil and gear, or selling unwanted items on the markets.

A contract of service can be drafted by <Color(-34022)>Frydwyb</Color> in Limsa Lominsa, <Color(-34022)>Parnell</Color> in Gridania, or <Color(-34022)>Chachabi</Color> in Ul'dah. Players may hire no more than two retainers at once.
Once a retainer is summoned, you can entrust her with gil or items, as well as have her put entrusted items up for sale in the markets.

To entrust an item to or retrieve an item from your retainer, simply drag it from one inventory window to the other. To transfer gil, click on the <Color(-34022)>Gil Transfer</Color> button to open a separate window.
To have your retainer put an item up for sale in the markets, click on the icon located in the upper right-hand corner of her inventory.

To entrust an item to or retrieve an item from your retainer, simply select it in the inventory window. To transfer gil, select the <Color(-34022)>Gil Transfer</Color> button to open a separate window.
To have your retainer put an item up for sale in the markets, select the icon located in the upper right-hand corner of her inventory.
Some gathering points will possess certain characteristics that, when exploited, may increase overall yield, chances of obtaining high-quality items, or number of gathering attempts.
Gathering point characteristics are displayed directly beneath a point's integrity bar, but only can be seen after acquiring one of the Disciple of the Land <Color(-34022)>Whisperer</Color> traits.

The higher your <Color(-34022)>perception</Color> rating, the better chance you have of obtaining high-quality (<Color(-34022)>HQ</Color>) items while gathering.

(Some items do not have an HQ counterpart.)

You can use the botanist action <Color(-34022)>Preparation</Color> to confirm how high your perception rating must be before you are able to obtain HQ items. The percentage displayed in the gathering interface indicates your chance of success.

Using certain actions or meeting certain attribute conditions can increase your chances of finding HQ items, but only if your perception rating is sufficient enough to obtain HQ items in the first place.

Botanists can use hatchets and other cutting tools to log the forests of Eorzea and gather materials for use in crafting. Trees that are prime for logging are known as <Color(-34022)>mature trees</Color>.

Mature trees are only discernible from other foliage when using the action <Color(-34022)>Triangulate</Color>. While this action is active, the location of mature trees is displayed on the <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>.
Once you have arrived at a mature tree, target it to begin logging.

Mature trees are only discernible from other foliage when using the action <Color(-34022)>Triangulate</Color>. While this action is active, the location of mature trees is displayed on the <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>.
Once you have arrived at a mature tree, target and select it to begin logging.
As many as eight different types of items can be found on a single gathering point. Begin gathering by selecting an item from the list that appears after right-clicking the target.

Your chances of successfully obtaining the selected item are displayed as a percentage to the right of its icon. Gear with a high <Color(-34022)>gathering</Color> rating will improve these chances, but only if your class level is at or above the item level (also displayed to the right of the item icon).

An item's position on the list is determined by its type. For example, <Color(-34022)>branches</Color> are always found in the third slot. Remembering which type of items are located in which slots will help you when coming across a new type of mature tree.
As many as eight different types of items can be found on a single mature tree. Begin logging by selecting an item from the list that appears after selecting the target.

A list of items available through gathering can be viewed by opening the <Color(-34022)>gathering log</Color>. This feature is accessible via <Color(-34022)>Logs</Color> in the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.
Items that you have successfully gathered at least once will appear with a check mark to the left of their icons. Gathering an item for the first time will earn you a special experience point bonus.
Certain items can only be obtained in certain areas. To confirm where an item might be found, refer to your gathering log.
The Disciple of the Land action <Color(-34022)>Stealth</Color> allows you to conceal yourself from enemies so that you may log, mine, or fish without fear of being attacked.

The one drawback to this command is that it reduces movement speed by almost half, so when there are no threats nearby, it is recommended that you cancel the status by selecting the Stealth icon on your <Color(-34022)>hotbar</Color> once again.

Stealth cannot be used if you are being attacked by an enemy. Also, enemies with levels significantly higher than yours may be able to detect you, regardless of whether or not you have Stealth activated.
The Disciple of the Land action <Color(-34022)>Stealth</Color> allows you to conceal yourself from enemies so that you may log, mine, or fish without fear of being attacked.

In addition to logging, botanists can use secondary tools to <Color(-34022)>harvest</Color> items from patches of foliage referred to as <Color(-34022)>lush vegetation</Color>. As is the case with mature trees, these locations are only discernible when using the action <Color(-34022)>Triangulate</Color>.
To harvest, you must first equip a <Color(-34022)>scythe</Color> to your <Color(-34022)>off hand</Color>. Scythes can be obtained from shops, markets, or quests.
You have obtained a whistle with which you can summon your very own minion! To learn the <Color(-34022)>Call Minion</Color> action, you must first <Color(-34022)>use</Color> the whistle.

Once you have used the item, a new entry will appear under <Color(-34022)>Minions</Color> in the <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color> menu. You can either initiate the action from this menu, or drag the icon, set it to one of your <Color(-34022)>hotbars</Color>, and initiate it from there.

To send your minion away, simply re-select the summoning icon.

Minions can be summoned or dismissed at any time, and the whistle has no recast timer. Once you have learned the summoning action, you will never lose it, and it can be used with all classes or jobs. You can only summon one minion at a time.
While minions do not generate any enmity, neither will they participate in battle. If you are KO'd, your minion will simply wander off back to wherever it is it rests until you call upon it again.

Once you have used the item, a new entry will appear under <Color(-34022)>General</Color> in the <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color> menu. You can either initiate the action from this menu, or set it to your <Color(-34022)>cross hotbar</Color> and initiate it from there.

To send your minion away, simply re-select the summoning icon.

Minions can be summoned or dismissed at any time, and the whistle has no recast timer. Once you have learned the summoning action, you will never lose it, and it can be used with all classes or jobs. You can only summon one minion at a time.
You are now able to <Color(-34022)>dye</Color> items! To dye a piece of gear, you must first have the proper colorant. Colorant can be crafted or purchased in stores.

Once you have the proper colorant, dyeing an item is as easy as selecting the <Color(-34022)>Dye icon</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color> interface.

There is no limit to how many times an item can be dyed. Dye can also be removed by using an item called <Color(-34022)>terebinth</Color>.

Similarly, if you wish to paint a housing fixture or furnishing, you can do so by selecting <Color(-34022)>Dye</Color> by accessing <Color(-34022)>Housing</Color> within the <Color(-34022)>Social</Color> menu. Alternately, furnishings can also be painted when selected from the inventory.

You can now convert items into materia!

Materia created from one piece of gear can be affixed to another, improving its attributes.

To convert an item into materia, you must have first created a <Color(-34022)>spiritbond</Color> with it by using the piece repeatedly in battle, crafting, or synthesis. Once an item's spiritbond reaches 100%, you will be able to select <Color(-34022)>Convert</Color> from the list of available subcommands.

Once an item is converted into materia, it can never be restored.

Affixing materia to an item can only be done by a Disciple of the Hand with the proper training.
マテリア化_パッド・3

You can now meld materia to items!

Gear can be enhanced significantly by affixing materia to the slots available on most weapons, tools, and armor. The number of slots available on a piece of gear can be confirmed by viewing its help text.

To affix materia to an item, highlight a piece of gear and select <Color(-34022)>Meld</Color> from the subcommands. Next, select the materia which you wish to affix. A catalyst of <Color(-34022)>carbonized matter</Color> is required to complete the meld. If you wish to remove materia from an item, you must visit Mutamix, as only he can do so.
マテリアクラフト_パッド・2
By learning the general action <Color(-34022)>Advanced Materia Melding</Color>, you can now attempt to attach materia to gear which has all its materia slots filled.

While the benefits of having multiple materia attached to your gear can be great, success is not guaranteed, and the consequences for failure can be great. A botched meld will result in the loss of not only the catalyst, but also the materia.

The type of gear determines which Disciple of the Hand class can meld materia to it. Items constructed of metal plate will usually require the talents of an <Color(-34022)>armorer</Color>. Cloth outfits, the talents of a <Color(-34022)>weaver</Color>. The level of an item also plays a role in who can or cannot enhance the gear.

If you lack the ability to meld your materia to an item, one option is to find a similar piece of armor with materia already attached. The <Color(-34022)>markets</Color> are a perfect place to find specially crafted items synthesized by Disciples of the Hand from across Eorzea.

Another option is to find another PC to meld the materia for you. One way to do this is via the <Color(-34022)>Player Search</Color> feature. Once you have found a PC capable of doing the meld and terms have been agreed upon, target the player and select <Color(-34022)>Request Meld</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>subcommands</Color>.

The Disciple of the Land actions <Color(-34022)>Truth of Forests</Color> and <Color(-34022)>Truth of Mountains</Color> enable you to detect <Color(-34022)>unspoiled</Color> gathering locations and display their location on the <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>. These special sites cannot be found with <Color(-34022)>Lay of the Land</Color> or <Color(-34022)>Arbor Call</Color>.

These elusive points are not always present, and once spent, may take hours or days to return. They have even been known to dissipate upon abandoning gathering, regardless of whether or not the point was depleted.

It is rumored, however, that there may be a pattern to when and where they appear...

Upon accessing certain high-level gathering points, you may find that items are <Color(-34022)>out of reach</Color>. To find out what these items are, you will have to spend your turns clearing away excess growth or debris.
If you are lucky, you may find a rare item. If not, you may find the slot barren. Either way, you will not know until the debris is removed.

The higher your <Color(-34022)>gathering</Color> rating, the more debris you will clear with each attempt. There are also high-level actions such as <Color(-34022)>Toil of the Pioneer</Color> and <Color(-34022)>Toil of the Mountaineer</Color> that, when used, instantly clear away all debris at a gathering point, allowing you to see where the items are located without having to use up your attempts.

Miners can use pickaxes and other digging tools to mine the mountains of Eorzea and gather materials for use in crafting. Locations that are prime for mining are known as <Color(-34022)>mineral deposits</Color>.

Mineral deposits are only discernible from other stones when using the action <Color(-34022)>Prospect</Color>. While this action is active, the location of mineral deposits is displayed on the <Color(-34022)>minimap</Color>.
Once you have arrived at a mineral deposit, simply target it to begin mining.

In addition to mining, miners can use secondary tools to <Color(-34022)>quarry</Color> items from patches of stone referred to as <Color(-34022)>rocky outcrops</Color>. As is the case with mineral deposits, these locations are only discernible when using the action <Color(-34022)>Prospect</Color>.
To quarry, you must first equip a <Color(-34022)>sledgehammer</Color> to your <Color(-34022)>off hand</Color>. Sledgehammers can be obtained from shops, markets, or quests.
To fish, you must first change your class to <Color(-34022)>fisher</Color> by equipping a <Color(-34022)>rod</Color> in your <Color(-34022)>main hand</Color>.

If the body of water you are near is fishable, the icon for the <Color(-34022)>Cast</Color> action will glow. Determine a bait to apply to your line by selecting the <Color(-34022)>Bait</Color> action and then checkmarking the desired item from the list that appears.

Some bait can only be used in certain locations or for landing certain types of fish. Bait and tackle can be harvested, made by Disciples of the Hand, or purchased from various merchants or fieldcraft vendors. Always make sure your inventory is stocked before heading out into the wild.

Your <Color(-34022)>fishing log</Color> contains invaluable information on everything from fishing hole locations, to detailed fish data, to personal records. The log can be found under <Color(-34022)>Logs</Color> in your <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

In addition to bait, there exist several types of man-made <Color(-34022)>lures</Color>. Lures are applied to your line in the same manner as bait.

Fish can sense the difference between live bait and lures; therefore it may take longer for you to register a bite.

On the other hand, lures can be reused multiple times, as well as employed to land prey too large for smaller bait. Being able to choose the right bait or lure for the situation is what separates the amateur from the professional.

<Color(-34022)>Mooching</Color> is a technique that involves catching a smaller fish, and then leaving that fish on the line to lure in a larger fish. Mooching can only be attempted if the first fish caught is of high quality <Emphasis>and</Emphasis> is suitable for mooching.

There are some varieties of large fish that can only be landed via mooching. Increase your <Color(-34022)>perception</Color> rating to increase your chances of landing a massive catch, and then use that fish to lure in an even rarer find.

No water, no problem! In Eorzea, experienced fishers find casting their lines into deserts (<Color(-34022)>dunefishing</Color>) and off mountain cliffs (<Color(-34022)>skyfishing</Color>) just as rewarding as casting them into a lake or river.
Once you have learned the <Color(-34022)>traits</Color> that unlock these special techniques, you will next need to equip your tackle box with special sky- and dunefishing bait.

The higher your <Color(-34022)>perception</Color> rating, the better chance you have of landing larger fish. Fish over a certain length are deemed high-quality (<Color(-34022)>HQ</Color>) and, depending on the variety, may be usable for <Color(-34022)>mooching</Color>.

Scattered about Eorzea there are legendary <Color(-34022)>fishing holes</Color> that only a handful of fishers can recognize amongst the normal waters. Once you have learned <Color(-34022)>Gulleye</Color>, perhaps you, too, can try your luck at these prime fishing locations.
A treasure coffer has appeared! Ofttimes, leve targets will drop treasure while being pursued. If you don't claim it, someone else will, so what are you waiting for?

You have discovered a wanted target. While not necessary to complete the leve objectives, defeating the enemy will earn you a portion of the bounty placed on its head. Take care, however, for these targets are usually quite powerful.

Grand Company leves are special missions available only to Grand Company members, and can only be accepted by speaking to a company officer. Completing one of these levequests will not only earn you items and experience, but company seals as well.

<Color(-34022)>Instanced raids</Color> are party-based content which take place in closed environments such as dungeons. The term “instanced” refers to the fact that these areas are reserved for a single group of players, meaning that you will not encounter any others during your time in them.

Parties must rely on their own wits and strength to conquer the many challenges that await them, such as deadly traps, complex mazes, and powerful bosses.

To add to the challenge, instanced raids have numerous requirements such as time limits, level restrictions, and limitations of changing classes or jobs while within.

Finally, raids can be joined either by forming a party and speaking with the NPC at the entrance, or by using the <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color> to automatically pair you with other adventurers around the world with the same ambitions.

Congratulations! You have just received your first <Color(-34022)>achievement</Color>! Achievements are earned by reaching certain milestones during your adventures in Eorzea, and there are achievements for just about everything─from leveling classes and uncovering locations, to defeating enemies and earning gil.

There are also rewards granted upon attaining certain achievements. Some of these include rare weapons and armor, others <Color(-34022)>titles</Color> which can be added to your display name to showcase your greatness.

Achievement rewards can be claimed from <Color(-34022)>Jonathas</Color> in Old Gridania.

The <Color(-34022)>Recommendations</Color> list displays quests or duties currently available in your area. Highlighting an item in the list will display further information regarding the duty, such as location.
Recommendations are helpful for finding quick gil and experience, or simply confirming if there are any quests or hunting log targets in the area you might have missed.

By unlocking the Duty Finder, you can now undertake multiplayer duties without having to form a party on your own.

Press the <Color(-34022)>U</Color> key or select <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color> to bring up the finder interface.

By unlocking the <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color>, you can now undertake multiplayer duties without having to form a party on your own.

Select <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color> to bring up the finder interface.

First, highlight a duty from the list and press the <Color(-34022)>Join</Color> button to begin the matching process. A <Color(-34022)>padlock icon</Color> indicates duty that cannot be accessed until you have achieved certain requirements such as level or quest completion.
Once you have registered, you can view the duty's particulars, including party and server status, by selecting <Color(-34022)>Duty Finder</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>.

When your party has been successfully formed, a confirmation prompt will appear.

Remember, it is good practice to work out a battle plan with your party before rushing headlong into an instance.

If someone has left your Duty Finder party, you can have the finder locate you a new member by using the <Color(-34022)>Add Member</Color> feature. Make certain you bring your new member up to speed on battle tactics once he or she arrives.

In the event multiple solo players attack the same target, the player who attacks first will <Color(-34022)>always</Color> receive <Color(-34022)>100%</Color> of the experience points and items dropped. The players who follow will be rewarded based on their contribution to the battle.

If you see a fellow player in need of a hand, do not hesitate to lend yours!

<Color(-34022)>Melee-oriented</Color> classes such as gladiator and marauder can chain together their <Color(-34022)>weaponskills</Color> to deal additional damage or inflict additional enfeeblements to their targets. This is known as a <Color(-34022)>combo</Color>.

※Combos are not available to pugilists, as this melee class employs a unique weaponskill chaining system.

If a weaponskill can be chained with another, it will be indicated in the weaponskill's help text under <Color(-34022)>Combo Action</Color>. In the case of <Color(-34022)>Vorpal Thrust</Color> (to the left), if executed immediately after <Color(-34022)>True Thrust</Color>, the potency will be double (200) that of a normal Vorpal Thrust (100).

Some weaponskills must be delivered from a specified <Color(-34022)>direction</Color> to maximize their damage. In these cases, maximum damage must be dealt for the action to successfully initiate a combo.

When a weaponskill can be chained into a combo, its <Color(-34022)>hotbar icon</Color> will be outlined with a flashing yellow border. The border will fade if the weaponskill is not used within a certain amount of time.

Learn which weaponskills chain together to maximize your battle efficiency.

<Color(-34022)>Astral Fire</Color> and <Color(-34022)>Umbral Ice</Color> are special status effects which allow thaumaturges to continuously deal devastating amounts of damage while still conserving their MP reserves.

Casting one of the <Color(-34022)>Fire</Color> spells gives a thaumaturge the effect of Astral Fire, which increases the potency and MP cost of further Fire spells. At the same time, it lowers the potency and MP cost of <Color(-34022)>Blizzard</Color> spells.

Conversely, casting one of the Blizzard spells gives a thaumaturge the effect of Umbral Ice, which increases the speed at which MP naturally recovers. At the same time, it lowers the potency and MP cost of Fire spells.

As a thaumaturge progresses in level, the number of Umbral Ice and Astral Fire effects which can be stacked at any one time increases─the larger the stack, the more powerful the effect.

Learning when to switch between fire and ice is key to being successful in extended battles.

Unlike other melee classes, pugilists do not use a system of weaponskill combos. Instead, weaponskills are used to cycle three unique battle <Color(-34022)>forms</Color> to achieve what is called <Color(-34022)> Greased Lightning</Color>─a status that increases attack power and speed, allowing them to overwhelm their enemies in a mad flurry of punches and kicks.

Many pugilist weaponskills will either change your form upon execution, or require you to be in a certain form to execute. There are also weaponskills which will grant damage bonuses when executed while in a certain form. The three types of forms are as follows: <Color(-34022)>opo-opo</Color>, <Color(-34022)>raptor</Color>, and <Color(-34022)>coeurl</Color>.
By successfully changing your form from opo-opo to raptor to coeurl, precisely in that order, you will earn the status Greased Lightning, which simultaneously increases attack speed and power.
As you increase in level, you will acquire the ability to stack the Greased Lightning status, allowing for even faster, more deadly strikes.

You can now summon a pet to do your bidding! You only have access to one pet now, but there will be opportunities to acquire many more as you continue your adventures.

Cast the spell <Color(-34022)>Summon</Color> from your hotbar to complete the arcane pact.

Once your pet is summoned, a fixed hotbar known as the <Color(-34022)>pet hotbar</Color> will appear in addition to your regular hotbars. The pet hotbar is preset with all the pet commands currently available to you, freeing up your normal hotbars for your personal actions and spells.

The <Color(-34022)>Guard</Color> command orders your pet to guard his master, refraining from attacking until you attack or are attacked. The <Color(-34022)>Steady</Color> command orders your pet to refrain from attacking until you specifically order him to do so. The <Color(-34022)>Away</Color> command orders your pet to leave the battlefield.

The <Color(-34022)>Sic</Color> command allows your pet to attack at will, while the <Color(-34022)>Obey</Color> command allows your pet to attack at will, but wait for your order before using special weaponskills or spells.
Pet orders and actions can also be set to your other hotbars by selecting them from the <Color(-34022)>Pets</Color> interface found within <Color(-34022)>Actions & Traits</Color>.

Once your pet is summoned, a separate hotbar known as the <Color(-34022)>pet hotbar</Color> can be accessed by pressing <CommandIcon(13)/>. The pet hotbar is preset with all the pet commands currently available to you, freeing up your normal hotbars for your personal actions and spells.

You have been granted entry to the <Color(-34022)>Wolves' Den</Color>! The floating arena is used by the Grand Companies of Eorzea as a training facility for their recruits. Inside the Pit, you will match your wits against other adventurers just like you. If you are interested in joining the fight, speak with the attendant on the <Emphasis>Braveheart</Emphasis>.

When a powerful enemy is readying a special attack during a quest battle, the <Color(-34022)>area of impact</Color> will begin to glow. Leaving the glowing area before the attack is initiated will ensure that you do not suffer any damage.

If an NPC has joined you in a quest battle, he or she will often provide you with hints displayed in a special text box near the top of the screen. Heed their words and you may just emerge victorious.

In addition to the reliving of past events and the understanding of unlearned languages, the Echo can provide you with extra strength when a battle turns sour. If you happen to be defeated during a quest battle, when you return for a second attempt, you will find that your attributes have been given a temporary boost.

Some quests require you to use a key item on an enemy target. There are two ways to do so.

The first is by right-clicking the enemy's <Color(-34022)>target bar</Color> and selecting <Color(-34022)>Use Key Item</Color> from the subcommands.
The second method is to first target an enemy, then click on the key item icon found in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>.

Some quests require you to use a key item on an enemy target. There are two ways to do so.

The first is by pressing <CommandIcon(10)/> and selecting <Color(-34022)>Use Key Item</Color> from the subcommands.

The second method is to first target an enemy, then press <CommandIcon(19)/> to access the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>. Use the directional keys to select the key item icon and press <CommandIcon(8)/> to complete the action.

You have changed to a new <Color(-34022)>battle class</Color>!

To lessen the burden of leveling multiple Disciple of War and Magic classes, an experience point bonus known as the <Color(-34022)>Armoury bonus</Color> is added when slaying enemies and participating in FATEs.
This bonus grows larger the greater the discrepancy between your current level and the level of your highest class. Use this to your advantage when deciding when and how to raise secondary classes.

Some key items are used on areas rather than single targets. First, click on the item icon displayed in the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>. Upon selecting the item, a <Color(-34022)>glowing radius</Color> will appear on the ground that can be moved freely with the mouse into the desired position before executing.

Some key items are used on areas rather than single targets. First, press <CommandIcon(19)/> to access the <Color(-34022)>duty list</Color>. Upon selecting the item and pressing <CommandIcon(8)/>, a <Color(-34022)>glowing radius</Color> will appear on the ground that can be moved freely into the desired position before executing.

After using the <Color(-34022)>Cast</Color> action to cast your line into the water, you need simply sit back and wait for a bite. When a fish bites, you will not only see the line being tugged, but hear it. While a fish is on the line, use the <Color(-34022)>Hook</Color> action to attempt to reel in your catch.
Your chances of successfully reeling in a fish after hooking it are directly affected by the fish type and your <Color(-34022)>perception</Color> rating.

<Color(-34022)>Allagan tomestones</Color> are relics of a long-lost civilization which perished several ages past. It is said that they contain the knowledge of the Allagan Empire, and as such are highly sought out by collectors around Eorzea.

<Color(-34022)>Rowena</Color> is a representative of one such collector, and has been sent to <Color(-34022)>Camp Revenant's Toll</Color> in the heart of <Color(-34022)>Mor Dhona</Color> by her employer to seek out adventurers willing to exchange the tomestones they come across on their journeys for weapons and armor.

Situated in your inn room, <Color(-34022)>the armoire</Color> can be used to store certain kinds of items with limited methods of obtainment. These include job-specific gear, seasonal event garb, and so forth.

Please note that only items with <Color(-34022)>condition</Color> at <Color(-34022)>100%</Color> can be stored. Furthermore, storing an item will reset its <Color(-34022)>spiritbond</Color> and remove customized elements such as dyes and crests.
Participating and winning in PvP battles will earn you a unique kind of experience points known as <Color(-34022)>PvP EXP</Color>. By accumulating PvP EXP, you will rise in PvP rank.

In turn, rising in PvP rank will earn you <Color(-34022)>Action Points</Color> (AP), which can be used to learn <Color(-34022)>PvP actions</Color>. As the name suggests, these actions can only be used during PvP.

You can view PvP information for your character such as rank and performance records, as well as learn PvP actions by selecting <Color(-34022)>PvP Profile</Color> within the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

You can view PvP information for your character such as rank and performance records, as well as learn PvP actions by selecting <Color(-34022)>PvP Profile</Color> within the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

Participating and winning in PvP battles will earn you a unique kind of currency known as <Color(-34022)>Wolf Marks</Color>. Wolf Marks can be exchanged for gear and other useful battle items by speaking with one of the Maelstrom soldiers stationed at the Wolves' Den.
Each of the three nations has established a <Color(-34022)>residential district</Color>, wherein like-minded adventurers can establish a base for their activities.

Each residential district is divided into <Color(-34022)>wards</Color>, which in turn house 30 plots of land each. Members of a free company may jointly purchase a plot of land upon which to build their own estate hall.
Estate halls can be customized by installing fixtures and placing furnishings. Please note that free company privileges are required for customization.
More information on housing can be had by speaking with the <Color(-34022)>resident caretaker</Color> stationed at each residential district.
By the entrance of each plot of land, you will find a <Color(-34022)>placard</Color>. Interacting with the placard will bring up information on the owner, if available.

In the event that the plot is <Color(-34022)>for sale</Color>, the current price will be displayed along with a <Color(-34022)>devaluation</Color> timer. Devaluation occurs every six hours (Earth time); the longer you wait, the cheaper the plot will become. However, the likelihood that another buyer will snap it up will also increase. More information on buying land can be had by speaking with the <Color(-34022)>resident caretaker</Color> stationed at each residential district.

This duty is designed to be undertaken by an <Color(-34022)>alliance</Color>, a squad of 24 adventurers formed of three <Color(-34022)>full parties</Color>. This battle composition is reserved for large-scale duties only.

While you are in an alliance, the class/job icons and HP bars of alliance members will appear to the right of the party list. By joining forces with other parties, you can achieve that which would otherwise be impossible.

You can receive only one reward item per week for completing duties in the Crystal Tower. The instant you are awarded an item from the loot list, you relinquish your right to vie for all remaining items regardless of whether you selected <Color(-34022)>Need</Color> or <Color(-34022)>Greed</Color>.

Completing an alliance objective will produce three treasure coffers, one for each party in the alliance. This means that your chance to obtain a reward is no less than that of other duties.

Reward eligibility is reset every Tuesday at midnight (JST).

The <Color(-34022)>Party Finder</Color> has been added to the <Color(-34022)>Social</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>. Through the Party Finder, you can either search for a party to join, or recruit other adventurers to form a party of your own.

To join a party, select <Color(-34022)>Search for Party</Color> and specify your <Color(-34022)>Search Criteria</Color>. Upon finding a compatible party, simply select <Color(-34022)>Join Party</Color>.

To recruit adventurers for your own party, select <Color(-34022)>Recruit Members</Color> and specify your <Color(-34022)>Recruitment Criteria</Color>. Interested individuals will answer the call, and you need only sit back and wait.

In the course of gathering, Disciples of the Land will occasionally come across <Color(-34022)>hidden</Color> items.

A hidden item may also be classified as <Color(-34022)>rare</Color>, meaning you can obtain only one before it disappears from the <Color(-34022)>Harvesting</Color> window. Abilities that increase the number of items obtained during a single gathering attempt have no effect on rare items.
In the course of gathering, Disciples of the Land will occasionally discover items known as <Color(-34022)>timeworn maps</Color>.
These maps can be examined by using the general action <Color(-34022)>Decipher</Color>.
If you wish to learn more about timeworn maps, it is recommended that you visit Wineport in eastern La Noscea.

By using the general action <Color(-34022)>Decipher</Emphasis>, you can examine a <Color(-34022)>timeworn map</Color>. Doing so will change it into a key item known as a <Color(-34022)>treasure map</Color>, which, true to its name, will reveal to you the location of a hidden cache of riches.

Please note that you can only possess one treasure map at any given time. If you wish to decipher another timeworn map, you must either find the current hidden cache, or simply discard the map leading to it.

Using a <Color(-34022)>treasure map</Color> will bring up a window that reveals the rough whereabouts of a hidden cache. It is then up to you to cross-reference the area map and pinpoint its precise location.
Upon arriving at the specified location, use the general action <Color(-34022)>Dig</Color> to locate and extract the treasure. Barring any navigational errors, a chest laden with bounty will appear.
Be fairly warned! The chest may be rigged with a trap that lures ferocious creatures to you. You must defeat them if you are to walk away with life, limb, and loot.

The beast tribes of Eorzea are beset with myriad problems. By helping each tribe resolve its issues through <Color(-34022)>beast tribe quests</Color>, you can improve your <Color(-34022)>reputation</Color> among its members.
The quests that are available change on a daily basis, and you can accept up to six in a single day. However, you cannot accept a new quest while the previous day's is still in progress.

To view your reputation among the beast tribes, select <Color(-34022)>Reputation</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>Character</Color> menu. By winning the trust of the beastmen, not only will you gain an insight into their lives; you will also be initiated into their mysteries.

Completing a <Color(-34022)>beast tribe quest</Color> will improve your <Color(-34022)>reputation</Color> with that tribe. When your reputation has risen sufficiently, you will be able to raise it to the next rank by undertaking a special quest.
As your bond with the beast tribe strengthens, you will be able to purchase an ever-expanding range of items from tribe vendors.
The beastmen deal in wares found nowhere else in the world, and the only way to obtain them is to win their trust!

Certain duties require you to carry an object and deliver it to a destination. While carrying an object, a <Color(-34022)>transporting icon</Color> will appear in your status bar. The number above this icon indicates the amount of time you have left to complete the delivery.

Receiving damage while transporting incurs a time penalty. If the timer falls to zero, you will drop the object and be unable to continue the duty.

Certain points along your route extend your transporting duration; use them wisely while avoiding confrontation.

Through sylphic magicks, you can become <Color(-34022)>transparent</Color> and infiltrate enemy territory undetected. While in this state, a  <Color(-34022)>transparent icon</Color> will appear in your status bar. The number below this icon indicates the amount of time you have left before the enchantment wears off.

Be warned that you cannot perform any actions while transparent. Initiating auto-attack will break the enchantment.

Certain points along your route extend the duration of your transparency; use them wisely while avoiding detection.
When riding certain mounts, a <Color(-34022)>pet hotbar</Color> featuring special actions will appear. These actions can be of great help in certain duties, so use them well.

You have befriended Jandelaine! By using the summoning bell found in your inn room, you can call upon the services of the flamboyant <Color(-34022)>aesthetician</Color>.
From hair style and color to face paint, he can create a new look for you for a mere <Color(-34022)>2,000 gil</Color>. Whenever you feel like a change, Jandelaine is your man.

When using the <Color(-34022)>Duty Roulette</Color>, you will be assigned a random duty from among those you have unlocked. In return for leaving your destination in the hands of fate, you will receive enhanced rewards.
Furthermore, should you happen to be an <Color(-34022)>adventurer in need</Color>─that is to say, your role is in short supply─you will receive an additional bonus.

<Color(-34022)>Vote dismiss</Color> is a function whereby players who are absent for extended periods or harass others can be democratically expelled from the party. To initiate a vote, first select <Color(-34022)>Party Members</Color> from the <Color(-34022)>Social</Color> section of the <Color(-34022)>main menu</Color>.

Next, select the party member you wish to nominate for dismissal, then <Color(-34022)>Vote Dismiss</Color> from the submenu. You will be required to select a reason for dismissal. Please be warned that unjustified usage of vote dismiss is a punishable act.
When vote dismiss is initiated, party members will be prompted for their response. If more than half vote <Color(-34022)>Yes</Color>, the player in question will be dismissed from the party.
<Color(-34022)>Player commendation</Color> is a system whereby you can commend a party member who left a positive impression upon you in the course of duty.

Upon the conclusion of a duty, the <Color(-34022)>Player Commendation button</Color> will appear in the bottom right of the screen. Selecting it will bring up an interface wherein you can commend a party member. Please note that commendations can only be made by those who joined a duty on their own, and not those in a party.
Commendations can be accumulated over time. By receiving a certain amount, you will unlock achievements that grant special rewards. It pays to play nice!
